awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: The Secondary Organic Aerosol Formation from the Oxidation of Furan-compounds to Understand the Atmospheric Impacts of Biomass Burning Smoke
awd_abstract_narration:
This project is investigating emissions from biomass combustion and the implications of these emissions on air quality and climate.  Laboratory studies will be conducted to quantify the emissions of furan compounds (i.e., those containing a 4-carbon, 1-oxygen aromatic ring) from biomass burning and to determine the fate of these compounds in the atmosphere.  The results of this project can be incorporated into the modeling of the impacts of biomass burning chemistry on local, regional, and global scales.

The specific objectives of this project are to:n(1) Identify the organic compounds produced by the OH and NO3 oxidation of furan compounds and quantify their contribution to the SOA yield; (2) Determine how this oxidation chemistry, and the O3 and SOA produced, varies with NMOC/NOx ratio, temperature, and RH; (3) Use the above results to develop a detailed mechanism for the oxidation of these furan compounds in biomass burning plumes; and (4) Quantify how this new mechanism alters the predicted impacts of biomass burning on atmospheric O3 and PM2.5.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Smoke from biomass burning (forest, grass, and crop fires) is a major air pollutant that can harm human health but quantifying the impact of the smoke on air pollution is difficult. In addition to uncertainties in the amount of smoke formed and the transport of the smoke in the atmosphere, the smoke can undergo chemical transformations that change the air quality impacts. These reactions include the aging of a wide variety of compounds emitted by biomass burning and the associated formation of two major air pollutants: ozone and fine particulate matter (PM2.5). However, many of the compounds emitted in the smoke have not had their chemistry studied in detail, and so how they affect air quality is hard to estimate.

In this project, we studied the aging of a specific class of compounds emitted in smoke called furan compounds (furfural and the methylfurans). These compounds are unique to biomass burning smoke and are thought to have a large impact on the formation of ozone and PM2.5 in the smoke as they age.  We performed a set of oxidation experiments in the Georgia Tech Environmental Chamber (GTEC) facility to study the chemistry of these compounds. The organic species produced in the oxidation were measured using an advanced technique (FIGAERO-HR-ToF-CIMS), which can provide molecular-level gas- and particle-phase composition data and is able to study the gas- particle partitioning and volatility of the products.

Our project was one of the first to study the formation of PM2.5 from the nighttime aging of furan compound, showing that the yields were similar to the daytime rates. We also showed that the formation of PM2.5 from these compounds is very sensitive to relative humidity, creating three to five times more PM2.5 under humid conditions. We also demonstrated that the aging of furan compounds can lead to the creation of light absorbing compounds, which are sometimes called brown carbon. Finally, we implemented advanced chemical mechanisms for the furan aging into a plume-scale model of the atmospheric chemistry of biomass burning plumes.
